posts.com:
>>18725620
Any sort of magnification will be helpful to show you the edge and a better view of the scratch pattern. I used this weird handheld microscope thing when I first started and I learned what to look for with what I had.

The edges I eventually got were outstanding. Jnats create extremely sharp edges that cut through beard hair with very little resistance, but feel dull or soft when running against your skin. Basically no redness after a 2 or 3 pass shave.

Ultra high grit synthetics create an edge some people find feels too sharp and harsh. If you're really into honing razors I would consider getting into jnats. The right stropping compound after a good hone will "soften" the edge, but it doesn't compare to a proper jnat edge.

Keiths economy shoubodani stones are really great beginner jnats, but they're still very expensive compared to synthetics. He sells some really great looking pastes. The ultra fine ones need your edge to be there before working properly tho.

Keith is a great dude. He gave me a free Japanese paring knife(>>18725498 this knife) with one of my orders around xmas. I've spent many thousands on super high end jnats over the years, and they never dissapoint. Unbelievable, godlike, stones. He hasn't dropped any super stones for a while, which is a bit of a bummer, but I can't really complain.

https://www.etsy.com/shop/TomoNagura

Look at this freehand knife edge I got from one of his stones. 200x magnification.

posts.com:
What annoys me isn't the limitations of cast iron - everything has limitations - but the people who fucking lie about it. The youtuber idiot "the cowboy kent rollins" or whatever the fuck he goes by is a perfect example of this kind of shill. He has videos where he takes a supposedly new pan and cooks bacon in it, then claiming that it didn't stick, even once.

Here's what happens to a new cast iron pan when you cook three slices of bacon in it. Each slice of bacon literally stripped the seasoning off the pan in the shape of each bacon slice.

That said,
>everything sticks even when copious amounts of oil/butter/etc are applied
>have to "season" it after every single use or it will shit the bed and die
>not allowed to wash it
I have other pans that are so well seasoned that I *can* cook bacon on them without any sticking or seasoning loss. However, when you get a new one, it can be a challenge to get to that point--and, once you get to that point, it's also possible to thin the seasoning so much in cooking with proteins that food sticks again. The key is, ironically, to actually wash the pan really well after cooking. Scrape off all the food, and use a chain mail rag if you need to, and cook in oil, at a very high heat, as much as possible during this time. Frying up potatoes is a really good way to build up seasoning.

Also, these are good points: >>18705004
>properly preheat the thing before cooking in it.
>>18705502
>When I start heating the pan I put a drop of oil, probably half a teaspoon or less for a 12-inch skillet, in the center and then spread it around with a crumpled sheet of paper towel.
I don't think too much oil is going to cause sticking, or at least I've never seen that happen when I cook with a lot of oil, but you really don't need much. Spreading a thin film of oil can even help prevent bacon from sticking. Preheating is KEY, though.

>>18705010
Preheating should not get it so hot it's exceeding the smoke point of your oil, wtf.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. Put 3 eggs in bowl and scramble with fork
2. Add pinch of salt and grind some black pepper in
3. Melt a little butter in a non-stick pan and lower it to low heat once melted
4. Add eggs and stir with long slow strokes to keep the curds long
5. Turn off the heat when the eggs just start to come together, the eggs cook themselves at that point
6. Serve on toast with chives if you have any

Easy, no gimmick ingredients, just eggs. Just cook low and slow and take it off before it's cooked how you like it.

>>18718242
boil water and cook noodles
in a separate pan fry up some bacon in a cold pan
add onions or leeks or shallots
maybe add some corn, peppers, mushrooms, potatoes or whatever else I have on hand to make a hash
saute with some garlic at the end, put aside
fry an egg or three
drain noodles a minute before they're ready, retaining some of the noodle water
mix noodles with ramen sauce, some sesame oil, and shredded cheese and hash
add egg on top
finish with sesame and/or ramen veggie seasoning
break egg yolk and eat with some more hot sauce
my go-to ramen with the buldak spicy ramen
kill it with a lager or some milk

A common way to eat quark is by adding fresh fruit like strawberries, a dash of milk and a bit of sugar.
Maybe that gives you an idea of what it's like. Eating cream cheese that way would be ridiculous.

>USDA choice "stew beef", sliced more finely
>potatoes (cut but unpeeled), carrots (cut but unpeeled), onions (chopped, not too small)
